_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ONEOK HYDROCARBON, L.P.

Mont Belvieu NGL Fractionation Facility
Baytown, Texas

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
FOR 
THE RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN


Introduction and Policies

ONEOK Hydrocarbon, L.P. (ONEOK) is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors and the public while fully complying with applicable laws and regulations.  ONEOK's management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of the Environmental Health and Safety Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators. 

This submission to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency updates the Mont Belvieu NGL Fractionation Facility Risk Management Program (RMP) to include a second fractionator, which has recently been constructed adjacent to the original fractionator and E/P Splitter unit.  The purpose of this Risk Management Plan is to provide information about operations at the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the event of an accidental release, the five-year accident history of the facility, and planned changes to improve safety at the facility.  


Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The Mont Belvieu Fractionation Facility receives raw feed via piping from an adjacent underground storage facility.  The raw feed is then fractionated into five purity products. These products are ethane, propane, isobutane, normal butane and natural gasoline.  The E/P Splitter receives EP Mix and splits it into purity ethane and propane.  The products are returned to the storage facility via plant piping and stored until they are delivered via pipeline to third party customers.  Ethane, propane, isobutane and normal butane as well as three flammable mixtures, natural gasoline, raw feed, and, EP Mix, are the flammable substances regulated under th

e Risk Management Program (RMP) that are present at the facility.  No toxic chemicals are stored at the facility in amounts greater than threshold quantity.  The facility is classified as Program Level 3 under the regulation. 


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs in place at the facility are part of the high standards striven for by ONEOK.  These high standards include:
-	Operating in compliance with required environmental permits and regulations.
-	Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that unintentional releases are minimized.
-	Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that the small releases associated with normal operation and maintenance will be minimized to the extent possible.
-	Correcting non-compliance found by regular audits of the facility.


Prevention Program

The facility will operate under the strict guidelines of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program.  Ongoing analysis of the potential hazards of the process, detailed training of employees and emphasis on safety will help to avoid any serious accidents in the future.  Part of this program also involves identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases.  A few examples of the prevention features implemented at this facility include:

-	Minimized the possibility that combustion of hydrocarbon vapors would be interrupted by having installed automatic pilot ignition and a failure alarm on the flare.
-	Installed fixed hydrocarbon detectors at point sources within the facility to help ensure that a release is detected and terminated as soon as possible.
-	Conduct preventive maintenance and vessel testing through the Mechanical Integrity program to help ensure that structural failures do not occur in process equipment.
-	Provide employees and contractors with an orientation on facility opera

tions to help ensure personal safety.
-	Provide a fire water system to help ensure quick response to fires.
-	Installed open path gas detectors to detect hydrocarbon releases.


Five Year Accident History

No incident resulting in onsite injuries, death or significant property damage or known offsite impacts, such as death, injury, property damage, shelter in place, evacuation, or environmental damage from a flammable substance release has occurred at the facility within the last five years. 


Emergency Response Program

Any emergency response necessary for the facility will be coordinated, as appropriate, with the Mutual Aid of Mont Belvieu (MAMB), the Mont Belvieu Fire Department, the Chambers County Sheriff, the Greater Baytown Area LEPC, the San Jacinto Hospital, and the Texas State Patrol.  The Director for Plant Operations, or his designee, is responsible for coordinating the emergency actions.  A specific Emergency Response Plan for the facility is in place and that plan has been communicated to local officials.  The Emergency Response Program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.


Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Compliance with the RMP Prevention Program, coupled with the Environmental Health and Safety Management Systems, forms the framework for continuous safety improvement.  Some of the key components of the safety program are:

-	The Management of Change provisions ensure that the potential safety and health impacts of any change made to process chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures are considered.
-	The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) combined with a Level of Protection Analysis (LOPA) serve as the tools to ensure timely evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in safety standards.
-	The Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that process equipment and piping are designed, constructed,

installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program.
-	Critical instrumentation is tested and maintained through preventative maintenance routines. 

Specific actions that will be taken in the future to improve the level of safety at the facility include:

-	Internal and third party compliance audits to ensure that the level of safety protection at the facility is periodically evaluated for improvements.
-	An ongoing dialogue with the Greater Baytown Area LEPC and Mutual Aid Mont Belvieu (MAMB) will ensure a constant state of readiness to respond to any potential emergencies, as well as a means to implement improvements as the need develops. 

All interested citizens or community organizations are encouraged to contact the Baytown Emergency Management Coordinator or his designate for the latest information on emergency response for the area.  The facility plans to coordinate its response capabilities and personnel with those of the city and county on an ongoing basis.
